He was one of the proprietors of Nelson Brothers' hotel and restaurant, 311 Washington avenue S, and was found dead in...
data.text:
DEATH CAUSED BY BLACK CIGARS

----------

Fred Nelson's Sudden Demise Attributed to Heavy Use of Havanas.

----------

Black Havana cigars are believed to have been the indirect cause of Fred Nelson's death. He was one of the proprietors of Nelson Brothers' hotel and restaurant, 311 Washington avenue S, and was found dead in his barn at the rear of his home, 3442 Bryant avenue S, this morning. Deputy Coroner Irvine was summoned and said that death was probably caused by heart disease. An autopsy will be held this afternoon.

Mr. Nelson worked at the restaurant until 2 o'clock this morning and immediately drove to his home. He was not seen alive again and his son found his dead body lying at the feet of his horse in one of the stalls in the barn when he went to care for the horse this morning.

Altho he was usually in good health, he had often been warned against too frequent use of black cigars. For some time he had smoked more than a dozen of them daily, but always said he noticed no bad results from their use.

The Minneapolis Journal

Minneapolis, Minnesota

Tuesday, June 21, 1904

Page 6

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

F. NELSON FOUND DEAD

------------

WAS WELL KNOWN AS A RESTAURANT PROPRIETOR.

------------

Coroner Investigates the Cause, but

It Is Supposed to Have Been Natural—Died at His Home.

------------

Fred Nelson was found dead in his barn at 3442 Bryant avenue south at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

The coroner has investigated the case, but has ascertained nothing bearing upon the cause of his death. His brother, Charles Nelson, with whom he was associated in business, stated that Fred left the restaurant at 2 o'clock yesterday morning and drove home.

Thy appearances Indicate, the coroner says, that Nelson, after unhitching the horse and tieing it into the stall, walked back toward the door, when be dropped dead. Death was sudden and without pain, as the face bore no signs of suffering.

When Mr. Nelson left for home yesterday morning he was apparently well and hearty, as neither his brother nor any of the employes had heard him complain of any ailment.

For a number of years Mr. Nelson with big brother has conducted a restaurant and hotel at 311 Washington avenue south.

His wife and children were absent from home at the time of his death.

An autopsy will probably be held on the body to determine the cause of death. It is believed, however, that death resulted from natural causes.

Deputy Coroner Irvine held an autopsy yesterday afternoon and pronounced death due to acute kidney trouble.

Star Tribune

Minneapolis, Minnesota

Wednesday, June 22, 1904

Page 7

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

FRED NELSON.—The funeral of Fred Nelson who died June 21 will be held from the home, 3442 Bryant avenue S. June 24 at 2 p. m. Friends are invited and members of Modin Tent No. 20, Knights of the Maccabees, of which Mr. Nelson was a charter member, are asked to attend in a body.

The Minneapolis Journal

Minneapolis, Minnesota

Wednesday, June 22, 1904

Page 6

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Emigration Record

Post 422843

Nilsson, Fredric

Dräng (unmarried man)

b. 7/6/1859 in Riseberga, Kristianstads län (Skåne)

Emigrated 3/29/1880

from Brandeborg 2, Riseberga, Kristianstads län (Skåne)

to Amerika

Source: Household Examination Roll, p. 138

Emibas migration file ID: Riseberga L 1880 009
